title: ANU to overhaul admissions policy to boost student diversity
text:
ANU to overhaul admissions policy to attract more students from disadvantaged backgrounds Posted February 09, 2017 16:07:09 Map: Canberra 2600 
The Australian National University (ANU) has announced it will look beyond admission rankings when selecting future students, saying the scores are excluding people from regional Australia and disadvantaged backgrounds. 
In announcing the university's five-year strategic plan today, Vice-Chancellor Brian Schmidt said from next year the university would move away from a sole reliance on admission rankings, or ATAR scores. 
While the ANU has yet to announce how it would manage future student intake, Professor Schmidt said the need for change was obvious. 
He said ATAR scores were too often skewed in favour of the best performing schools in Australia's bigger cities. 
"Our ATAR this year in law is 98," he said. 
"That essentially excludes everyone from rural Australia and that's a bad thing that we need to change. 
"We need to make sure we represent the whole of Australian society, so that's why we need to change it." 
The ANU also outlined its plans to be more inclusive by recruiting more senior female staff and attracting students from other cultural backgrounds. 
Professor Schmidt said the university should lead the nation in setting new diversity and gender benchmarks. 
"We have to be elite, but not elitist where we exclude people because they have not been born into this university," he said. 
"I think it's very important to make sure that we don't allow the word elite to be hijacked from us. 
"We want to rise to the challenge of being a national university that serves our society and reflects our society in all its diversity." New York composer to head School of Music 
In another major announcement today, the ANU appointed Ken Lampl, a former teacher at New York's famous Juilliard School, to lead the ANU School of Music, which has been without an official head since August 2015. 
Professor Schmidt said Mr Lampl had written music for more than 70 films, TV shows and video games and had "played alongside some of the world's greatest jazz musicians". Photo: Ken Lampl is an internationally recognised composer. (ANU: Stuart Hay) 
The school has had a tumultuous few years after a major restructure in 2012 resulted in job losses , funding cuts, and a drop in services offered, including the axing of one of two undergraduate courses, and a reduction in one-on-one teaching opportunities. 
Today Professor Lampl was named to lead the school along with Paul McMahon as deputy head. 
Professor Lampl said he was excited to build a modern school of music from the ground up. 
"They can expect the highest calibre of performance training and concerts from the students, the highest calibre of teaching, the highest calibre of research, all in a very 21st century context," he told ABC Radio Canberra. 
Dr McMahon said they had been appointed at "a crucial time for the school". 
"We know what the university, the community and the profession expect from the school," he said. 
"We now want to deliver so many of those expectations, within a framework of strong education, quality practice and insightful research."
